text: <@UF2GNRUTV> is `(+)` a function that maps integers to integers though seeing as it takes two elements?  The groupish way model addition on integers is as a single object with an arrow for each integer.  `(+)` serves as the composition operation and `0` is the identity.  Similarly you get a different monoid (not a group because missing inverses) for `(*)` and `1`.

text:
had to hop off for a work meeting. i think it can probably pose my question from the call a bit more tightly. and i think these are equivalent:
- is the cardinality of the morphisms from A to B ever matter, in pure category theoretical reasoning?
- given objects A, B, and C, is the category with only A->B and B->C identical (in a purely category theoretical sense) to the category with A->B, B->C, and A->C?
- is there a distinction between "original morphisms" and morphisms that result from composition?

i hypothesize that the laws of category theory don't give us a way to distinguish, without resorting to inspecting the underlying things. i think this may be true because that's what would make this whole concept super powerful, because of just how portable proofs would be if these distinctions can't be made within the rules

elements.text:

text: (referencing the end of the call) yeah it’s weird how mathematicians often invent tools because they’re helpful for a particular problem, like group theory—but then when they’re trying to teach them they skip the whole part of the story which is “this is what motivated me to make this tool” which i think is really helpful context

text: My impression is that we can't inspect inside an object (for example, we can't point at members of a set) but we can refer to specific morphisms by name. For example in the category of types and functions, (+1) and (/ 7) are both morphism from Int to Int.

text: One thing I wanted to talk about (but maybe we can do next time or on Slack in a thread) was this post about compositionality vs modularity. In particular the phrase "Compositional with respect to what? Which properties are preserved when composing things together?"  <https://blog.statebox.org/modularity-vs-compositionality-a-history-of-misunderstandings-be0150033568>

attachments.title: Modularity vs Compositionality: A History of Misunderstandings
attachments.text: I claim that compositionality is extremely delicate, and that it is so powerful that it is worth going to extreme lengths to achieve it…

text: > So, when someone claims that a system is compositional, one should immediately ask “Compositional with respect to what? Which properties are preserved when composing things together? Which kind of behavior are we able to completely predict and characterize when different parts of the system interact?”

elements.text: So, when someone claims that a system is compositional, one should immediately ask “Compositional with respect to what? Which properties are preserved when composing things together? text:
> but identity morphisms are distinguished from all other in a way that is clear in pure category theory: its source and destination are the same

In the category of types and functions, there are many such morphisms that have the same source and destination. For example, the object/type Int has a (+1) morphisms and a (+7) morphism starting and ending in itself

elements.text: but identity morphisms are distinguished from all other in a way that is clear in pure category theory: its source and destination are the same

In the category of types and functions, there are many such morphisms that have the same source and destination. For example, the object/type Int has a (+1) morphisms and a (+7) morphism starting and ending in itself

text: One morphism is identified as the identity, but you could add a second that works the same way so that you wouldn't be able to tell which one is the blessed identity.

elements.text: One morphism is identified as the identity, but you could add a second that works the same way so that you wouldn't be able to tell which one is the blessed identity.

text: Our discussion about multiple arrows between objects (or on a single object) reminds me of how Seven Sketches handles this: they introduce partial orders in the first chapter (one arrow or zero arrows between any two object, and therefore only the identity arrow form a single object to itself).  They talk about all the regular categorical constructs (limits, functors, adjoints – this words will mean something to you later) in the context of partial orders, so you already have a grounding before the same ideas are extended to categories in general.

elements.text: Our discussion about multiple arrows between objects (or on a single object) reminds me of how Seven Sketches handles this: they introduce partial orders in the first chapter (one arrow or zero arrows between any two object, and therefore only the identity arrow form a single object to itself).  They talk about all the regular categorical constructs (limits, functors, adjoints – this words will mean something to you later) in the context of partial orders, so you already have a grounding before the same ideas are extended to categories in general.

text:
i'm convinced my hypothesis was wrong. here are things i now believe to be true:
- in a category, if there is an (A -> B) ∘ (B -> C), there is a corresponding A -> C. but there may be other A -> C, too
- furthermore, it's possible to for there to be multiple morphisms mapping an object to itself. however, the identity morphism appears to be unique.
- the composition of an identity morphism with itself is not considered to be a different morphism than that same identity morphism
- in the web example, the web is a category if webpages are objects and link-clicks are morphisms as long as refreshing a page counts as the identity morphism. a click on a self-link could be considered a distinct morphism from a refresh. or not. these would be two different categories

this comment captures my confusion about what types of identity matter in category theory (in the sense of distinctiveness, not in the sense of an identity function) <https://bartoszmilewski.com/2014/12/05/categories-great-and-small/#comment-36885>

elements.text:
i'm convinced my hypothesis was wrong. here are things i now believe to be true:
- in a category, if there is an (A -> B) ∘ (B -> C), there is a corresponding A -> C. but there may be other A -> C, too
- furthermore, it's possible to for there to be multiple morphisms mapping an object to itself. however, the identity morphism appears to be unique.
- the composition of an identity morphism with itself is not considered to be a different morphism than that same identity morphism
- in the web example, the web is a category if webpages are objects and link-clicks are morphisms as long as refreshing a page counts as the identity morphism. a click on a self-link could be considered a distinct morphism from a refresh. or not. these would be two different categories

this comment captures my confusion about what types of identity matter in category theory (in the sense of distinctiveness, not in the sense of an identity function)
